metadata.title: Performance analysis of ultrasound-assisted synthesized nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst in the methanol-to-lights-olefins process via artificial intelligence methods

Performance analysis of ultrasound-assisted synthesized nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst in the methanol-to-lights-olefins process via artificial intelligence methods Mohammad Javad Azarhoosha, Rouein Halladjb, Sima Askaric, Abbas Aghaeinejad-Meybodia,⁎
a Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Urmia University, P.O. Box 57561-51818, Urmia, Iran b Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology (Tehran Polytechnic), P.O. Box 15875-4413, Tehran, Iran c Department of Chemical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, P.O. Box 14778-93855, Tehran, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Ultrasound-assisted synthesis Nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 MTO process Multi-linear regression Artificial neural network Genetic programming Genetic algorithm
A B S T R A C T
The present study has focused on performance analysis of ultrasound-assisted synthesized nano-hierarchical silico-alumino-phosphate-34 (SAPO-34) catalyst during methanol-to-light-olefins (MTO) process. A classical method, i.e., multiple linear regression (MLR) and two intelligent methods, i.e., genetic programming (GP) and artificial neural networks (ANN) were used for modeling of the performance of nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst. We studied the influence of basic parameters for the sonochemical synthesis of nano-hierarchical SAPO34 catalyst such as crystallization time, ultrasonic irradiation time, ultrasonic intensity, amount of organic template (diethylamine (DEA) and carbon nanotube (CNT)) on its performance (methanol conversion and light olefins selectivity) in MTO process.
The results revealed that the models achieved using the GP method had the highest accuracy for training and test data. Therefore, GP models were used in the following to predict the effect of main parameters for the sonochemical synthesis of nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst. Finally, an optimal catalyst with the highest yield into light olefins was predicted using the genetic optimization algorithm. The genetic models were employed as an evaluation function in the genetic algorithm (GA). A good agreement between the outputs of GP models for the optimal catalyst and experimental results were obtained. The optimal ultrasound-assisted synthesized nanohierarchical SAPO-34 was accompanied by light olefins selectivity of 77% and methanol conversion of 94% from the onset of the process after 9 h.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ethylene, propylene, and butylene are used mainly as light olefins in the petrochemical industries [1,2]. The methanol-to-light-olefins (MTO) process using a non-oil source as an alternative method has been considered due to the shortage of oil resources in the future and the industries growing demand to light olefins [3,4]. Among the catalysts that used for the MTO process, SAPO-34 is the most proper catalyst due to small pores and moderate acidity [5,6]. SAPO-34 is a silico-aluminophosphate micro-pore molecular sieve with chabasite (CHA) structure that has a suitable catalytic performance in the MTO process. This catalyst has a very high selectivity for producing light olefins by almost complete methanol conversion, because of mild acidity, shape selectivity due to its small entry pores, and thermal stability [28]. One of the main problems of the MTO process is rapid deactivation of SAPO-34 catalyst, which could be because of the synthesis factors, hence, the
catalyst performance could be optimized by adjusting the synthesis conditions [7,8].
The ultrasonic-assisted synthesis of the SAPO-34 catalysts is one of the promising methods for improving its performance in the MTO process [9–11], which has also been adopted in the present study. In fact, the ultrasonic radiation to the initial solution during the preparation of the precursor gel (prior to the start of the hydrothermal process) leads to its uniformity and significantly improves the initial nucleation [12]. The results of previous studies were indicative high crystallinity, narrow distribution of particle size, and a significant increase in the external surface of the synthesized catalyst. The synthesized catalyst was along with a much higher selectivity and lifetime compared to the conventional catalysts [13–15].
Synthesize of SAPO-34 catalysts with a hierarchical structure is another approach for the increase of its performance [16–19]. In this method, macro pores (pores with diameters (dp) > 50 nm) and Meso

pores (2 nm < dp < 50 nm) are added to the structure of zeolite, which contains micro-pores (dp < 2 nm) [20–22]. Nowadays, this method has been examined in studies with a growing number in recent years [23–25]. In this method, in addition to the use of base microporous templates such as tetraethyl ammonium hydroxide (TEAOH), diethylamine (DEA), etc., other templates are also utilized to create meso-pores in the structure of the SAPO-34 microporous structure [26–29].
Ren et al. [30] synthesized the hierarchical SAPO-34 base catalyst using a hydrothermal method and then placed it in nitric acid and oxalic acid solutions for 6 h. Finally, the catalysts were separated by filtration and calcinated after washing with water. The results indicated that the fabricated catalyst had a hierarchical structure and higher acidic sites in comparison with the base catalyst, hence increasing the lifetime of the catalyst in the MTO process (increasing from 210 to 390min) and leading to a higher light olefins selectivity (from 92% to 94%) [30].
Mousavi et al. [31] used polyethylene glycol (PEG) as the agent to create the meso-pores in the hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst. PEG leaving the structure in the calcination process in synthesized catalysts led to the creation of a hierarchical structure in the catalysts, which greatly enhanced the performance of the MTO process [31].
In the hydrothermal synthesis of the hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst, Yang et al. [32] utilized phenylaminopropyltrimethoxysilane (PHAPTMS) as a silicon source and also as a template to create mesopores as well as TEAOH as a microporous template. The use of PHAPTMS in the primary gel led to the creation of meso-pores inside the SAPO-34 microporous structure, and the hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts were produced with an average particle size of 50 nm. In the MTO process, these catalysts displayed a high degree of stability and light olefins selectivity.
Rimaz et al. [33] applied carbon nanotube (CNT) as a hard template and DEA as a microporous template in the synthesis of hierarchical SAPO-34 using the dry gel technique. The results revealed an increase in the outer surface of the synthesized catalyst as well as the creation of a hierarchical structure, resulting in a significant improvement of the catalyst performance in the MTO process [33].

sections.heading: 1.1. Problem statement and goals of this study
sections.text:
In this research work, an ultrasonic-assisted hydrothermal synthesis was applied to the synthesis of the nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts. These catalysts were synthesized with CNT as a template creating pores with meso and macro sizes and DEA as the microporous template [27]. Also, the effects of main parameters such as crystallization time, amount of templates, ultrasonic irradiation time and power intensity on the performance of synthesized nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 have been investigated and modeled in the MTO process.
For this purpose, first, a set of 40 catalysts was randomly synthesized and its performance was investigated in the MTO process. Common experimental design methods – i.e., full or partial factorial method, and response surface method (RSM) – need a large number of tests in case of the high number of input factors, which is not economically cost-effective. Therefore, in these methods the level numbers must be limited. In addition, due to the limited number of levels, the results of modeling are usually not along with high accuracy for experiments with parameter values other than level values. Therefore, in this study, a randomized test design method has been exploited in which each factor has an unspecified number of levels. The advantages of this method include reduction of the number of experiments required, lack of limitation in the experiments at specific levels of influential factors, and hence the higher accuracy of the presented models. Then, classical modeling methods such as MLR (multiple linear regression) and intelligent methods such as GP (genetic programming) and ANN (artificial neural networks) models were presented aiming to predict the effect of synthesis conditions on the performance properties of the synthesized catalysts in the MTO process such as light olefins selectivity and methanol conversion. In the following, among the above-mentioned models, a model with the highest accuracy and the highest prediction power was adopted to examine the influence of operating parameters and selection of optimum catalyst. Finally, the efficiency of the optimal predicted catalyst was compared with experimental results.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis and characterization of catalyst
sections.text:
For SAPO-34 synthesis, initial solution with the molar composition of 1Al2O3: 1P2O5: 0.6SiO2: xCNT: yDEA: 70H2O was used using aluminum isopropoxide (Merck, Germany, ≥98wt%, 220418), tetraethylortosilicate (TEOS, Merck, Germany, ≥99wt%, 8006580250) and phosphoric Acid (Merck, Germany, 85 wt%, 1005731000) as aluminum, silicon and phosphor source, respectively (x and y are varied in different samples). First, the required amount of distilled water, DEA (Merck, Germany, ≥99wt%, 8030100500) and aluminum isopropoxide were mixed together and stirred for 1 h. Next, the mixing process continued for 2 h after adding the required amount of TEOS to the solution. Afterwards, phosphoric acid was added to the solution as dropwise and until the white gel was obtained, the mixing process continued. In the next stage, the CNTs (Merck, Germany, ≥98wt%, 901051) were added to the solution and the solution was stirred for 1 h [27].
Then, in the crystallization step, the obtained solution was placed under ultrasonic irradiation (with different time and intensities for different samples). Finally, the obtained gel was inserted in the autoclave (stainless steel Teflon) and placed in the oven (Tebazma, Iran, OT53) at 200 °C for a desired period time, which varied for various samples [27].
In the crystallization stage, a two-phase solution was obtained, that was centrifuged at a rate of 600 rpm in order to separate its solids from the liquid. The separated solids were washed with distilled water after each separation and re-separation was performed through centrifugation. The separation and washing steps were conducted for 3 times. For drying the solid washed material, it was inserted it in the oven for 5 h at 110 °C. In the final stage, to remove organic templates, the calcination process was carried out for 5 h at 640 °C. The various steps of catalyst synthesis are demonstrated in Fig. 1. From previous studies [14,27], the minimum and maximum values of the important parameters in the synthesis of the nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst were specified for the experiment design, as presented in Table 1. To investigate the shape and size of the crystals, the field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) analysis, which is one of the most widely used methods in this regard, was employed. For this purpose, a FESEM device (TESCAN, Czech Republic, MRI A3 TESCAN-XMU) was exploited to perform the analysis. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis using the BET device (Quantachrome, USA, Autosorb-1) device was used for determination of the specific surface area of the optimal catalyst. The optimal outer specific surface area of the optimal sample (Sext) and the volume of the micropores (Vmicro) was calculated using the t-plot model, the total specific surface area (SBET) using the BET model, and the volume of the mesopores (Vmeso) as well as the mesopore size distribution using the BJH method from the exclusion branch of the isotherm curve.

sections.heading: 2.2. Processing test
sections.text:
The schematic of the reactor system has been presented in Fig. 2. For the activation, a flow of nitrogen gas with the flow of 100 cc/min was passed over the catalyst for 1 h at 500 °C before the start of any reaction. After the catalyst recovery, the nitrogen gas valve was closed and the feed valve was opened, and a 20% by volume solution of methanol (99.9 wt%, Merck) and water were pumped into the fixed bed reactor. After the reaction, the flow leaving the reactor entered the condenser and its temperature was decreased to prevent secondary reactions. At this stage, the water and heavy hydrocarbons, if any, and unreacted methanol were condensed and accumulated in the condenser. The remaining gas flow was transmitted to the gas chromatograph (GC) for analysis or to the outside environment.
In addition to the feed flow of methanol and water entering the reactor, there was another flow that was connected to the nitrogen gas capsule. Due to the time interval between reactor synthesis and testing, nitrogen gas was utilized for dehumidification and recovery of the catalysts. This step was carried out prior to the onset of the reaction at
500 °C for 1 h with a flow rate of approximately 100ml/min. A bubble flow-meter was used to adjust the flow rate before injection.
The MTO reactions takes place in a tubular fixed bed reactor (internal diameter: 15mm) with different catalysts. Due to the low pressures of the MTO process, the evaluation of the performance of different catalysts in this process was conducted at atmospheric pressure. To carry out the MTO reaction at the desired temperature, the temperature of the reactor was controlled by an electric furnace equipped with a PID (proportional integral derivative) controller. The sensor of this controller can be moved in the central part of the reactor and placed in the zone where the catalyst was located, so that the catalyst bed temperature was adjusted to the reaction temperature. In tests regarding the performance of the catalysts, all tests were performed at 450 °C, the flow rate of input feed about 0.47ml/min, and 1 g of SAPO-34 catalyst and 4.5 h−1 of methanol WHSV (weight hourly space velocity)[27].
The analysis of the reaction products was performed using an online GC (Agilent, USA, 6890 N), equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and plot-Q column. Methanol conversion and dry basis light olefins selectivity are defined as below:

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Multi linear regression (MLR)
sections.text:
MLR is used when some independent variables are used to predict a dependent variable. In this method, a relationship between independent and dependent variables is predicted using a linear polynomial. Even in case of the lack of a sensible physical relationship
among variables, they can be related to each other with a mathematical relationship. Although this function may be physically meaningless, it can be very important for predicting the values of a variable in terms of the data associated with other variables [13,34]. Different modeling and optimization methods were done in MATLAB R2018b software.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Artificial neural network (ANN)
sections.text:
Nowadays, ANN as one of the fields of artificial intelligence, is used as a powerful tool for implementing complex functions in various fields. Neural networks are a very suitable tool for function fitting and pattern recognition, and it can be proved that simple neural networks are capable of fitting any operational function [35–38].
Among the types of neural networks, multilayer feed-forward neural networks have the highest usage in fitting and predicting of operational functions. These types of networks consist of three layers of neurons: input layer, hidden layer(s), and output layer. It should be mentioned that each layer consists of several neurons. The number of neurons of the input layer is based on the number of operating parameters (independent variables), and the number of neurons of the output layer is based on the number of target variables. However, a trial and error method is used to determining the optimal number of neurons in the hidden layer(s) [13,39].
In this section, the multilayer feed-forward neural networks have been employed to predict the physio-chemical and process properties of the nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts. 70% of the data (28 data) were used as training data, 10% of data (4 data) as validation data, and the rest (8 data) as test data. It should be noted that the data were randomly divided. Since the number of data was limited, a separate ANN was designed for each dependent variable. Using the trial and error method, the number of neurons in the hidden layer was chosen equal to 4. ANNs created by the back propagation method were trained using the Levenberg-Marquardt learning rule.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Genetic algorithm
sections.text:
The classical methods such as goal-programming method and goalattainment method, or evolutionary methods including GA, ant colony (ACO) algorithm, and Particle swarm optimization (PSO) can be applied in optimization [40]. In recent years, in solving complex problems, evolutionary algorithms such as GA have been much more
effective compared to the classic methods [41–44]. One of the most important algorithms with random search technique is GA. the idea of GA has been derived from the nature and Darwin’s theory. This algorithm is widely used to solve of optimization problems. More suitable generations are formed from more suitable chromosomes in nature. Meanwhile, some mutations occur in the chromosomes, which can result in better future generations. This idea is used in genetic algorithms to solve problems [45,46]. Table 2 indicates the characteristics applied in the GA code of this study.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Genetic programming (GP)
sections.text: The GP method was introduced by Koza in 1992 as an extension of the GA approach, in which programs (solutions) are represented as tree structures and in a functional programming language. Overall, this method can be described as a comprehensive instrumental approach that searches the problem space rather than the data space. In other words, GP is an optimization and regression provision method generating solutions to solve the problem with the Darwin's principle of natural selection. Using this solution, the desired solution to the problem can be achieved or at least the final response can be estimated without the need for explicit programming. The GP ability in finding the solution with the best fit with the data points, without a presumption of the model structure, has been found to be very effective. This solution is ultimately presented as a mathematical relation [47,48]. The features applied in the GP code used in this study are given in Table 3.

sections.heading: 2.4. Mechanism of the ultrasound in the synthesis process of SAPO-34
sections.text:
Sonochemical synthesis by US irradiation (20 kHz–10MHz) is a new method for synthesis of nanoparticles especially nanocatalysis [11–14]. Contrary to conventional methods (mainly hydrothermal synthesis), this method is very simple, fast, and does not need any complicated facilities. In this method, the size of particles can be easily controlled by changing the ultrasound-related variables [11,13]. Chemical effects of US waves are due to acoustic cavitation phenomena in the solution. Due to the collapse of bubbles, a temperature and pressure of about 5000–25,000 K and 181.8MPa are produced [11,13]. Collapsing of bubbles occurred in less than a nanosecond and so, a high rate of temperature decrease (1011 K/s) takes place, which prevents the organization and agglomeration of particles [11–13].
Because of cavitation effect, which can create high temperature and high pressure in a solution, the ultrasonic treatment can influence the crystallization kinetics and the formation of crystal nuclei. Ultrasound seems to also influence the physicochemical phenomena related to nucleation and crystal growth, occurring during crystallization [12,14]. For instance, it was observed that ultrasonic waves decrease the supersaturation limits and modify the morphology of postash alum crystals. In this case, the average crystal size decreased with an increase in ultrasonic power [14]. Applying ultrasound was also shown to affect the primary nucleation of potassium sulphate, by leading to reductions in the induction time and the metastable zone width of this material [12,14].
Due to non-homogenous zeolites, which are prepared by hydrothermal crystallization, the degree of control over their preparation and properties bears importance [14]. In this respect, the nucleation and
crystal growth rates, and the resulting particle size distribution are especially important to tailor. The molar ratios of the reactants, and the synthesis time and temperature are the main parameters in determining the type and properties of the zeolite formed. Ultrasound can enhance and alter dissolution processes, chemical reactions, nucleation and growth of precipitates [14]. It is extremely useful in crystallization processes since it can initiate seeding and control subsequent crystal growth in a saturated or supercooled medium [12,14].

sections.heading: 3.1. Investigating the role the ultrasound-assisted hydrothermal synthesis
sections.text:
In this section, a comparison between structural characteristics and performance of two catalyst samples synthesized by ultrasound-assisted hydrothermal (SONO-SAPO-34) and hydrothermal (HT-SAPO-34) is investigated. In both catalysts, CNT/Al2O3, DEA/Al2O3 in initial gel and crystallization time are 1, 2 and 6 h, respectively. In SONO-SAPO-34 the, the obtained solution was placed under ultrasonic irradiation before crystallization step (US time=20min and US irradiation intensity= 243W.m−2). Results obtained from XRD for HT-SAPO-34 and SONO-SAPO-34 samples are presented in Fig. 3. The only difference between these samples is in the using of ultrasound in the catalyst synthesis. According to the observed peaks and their comparison with the reported peaks for SAPO-34, both of the samples are pure and the amorphous phase is not seen in the samples. It is observed that XRD of
these samples have different peak intensities and SONO-SAPO-34 sample has more peak intensities than HT-SAPO-34, which demonstrates that ultrasound-assisted hydrothermal synthesis can increase the peak intensities and, consequently, crystallinity.
The images obtained from FESEM analysis of all samples are presented in Fig. 4. As can be seen in this figure, HT_SAPO-34 catalyst, which was synthesized using hydrothermal method, is composed of cubic crystals. Using the ultrasound waves in SAPO-34 synthesis remarkably changes the morphology and decrease the size of particles so that, in SONO-SAPO-34 sample, spherical nanoparticles are seen instead of cubic particles, which is the common shape for SAPO-34. It can be stated that with using of ultrasound waves, a large number of
primary crystals are formed with very small sizes [14]. Moreover, the ultrasound waves influences the reduction of particle agglomeration significantly. The first reason is that the huge amount of energy created because of collapse of cavitation bubbles results in a high temperature reduction in the reaction medium and preventing particle agglomeration. The second reason is that the solution is very well mixed because of the higher intensity of ultrasound waves, it can prevent the adhesion and accumulation of primary crystalline nuclei through controlling their number, as these nuclei can accumulate in different parts of the reaction environment [14].
Table 4 shows the results of N2 adsorption-desorption analysis of both samples. The results show that the SONO-SAPO-34 has more surface of micro-pores, external surface and BET surface than HT-SAPO34. Fig. 5 demonstrates the performance of HT-SAPO-34 and SONOSAPO-34 catalysts in MTO process, in which SONO-SAPO-34 catalyst has the better performance than HT-SAPO-34.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. ANN modeling results
sections.text:
To prediction of MTO process performance of the nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts, the multilayer feed-forward neural networks were used. 70% of the data (28 data) were used as training data, 10% of data (4 data) as validation data, and the rest (8 data) as test data. Since the number of data was limited, a separate ANN was designed for each dependent variable, and according to trial and error technique, 4 neurons was considered for the hidden layer. ANNs created by the back propagation method were trained using the Levenberg-Marquardt learning rule. Fig. 7 demonstrated an overview of optimum neural networks designed to predict objective variables.
The performance of ANNs has been measured to predict the dependent variables using R2 and RMSE and presented in Table 6. The comparison of the actual values of the process performance of the catalysts with the values predicted by ANNs has been shown in Fig. 8. This figure shows that there is a very good agreement between the ANN models and experimental values for train data set. But the accuracy of ANN models were not desirable because of low number of data.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Selection of the best modeling method
sections.text: In this part of the study, the best modeling method has been determined by the obtained results of models in the previous sections (Table 6). The results obtained by three models of MLR, ANN, and GP indicated that the artificial intelligence-based methods (ANN and GP) were accompanied by a much higher accuracy in comparison with the classical methods (regression). In fact, intelligence-based methods can be used as powerful tools for implementing complex functions in various fields and it can be proved that these methods are capable of fitting any operational function. However, as it can be seen, the models derived from GP have higher R2 values and lower RMSE values compared to ANNs for all test values. The reason for the low accuracy of ANNs can be attributed to the relatively low number of data. Furthermore, the accuracy of the prediction of genetic models for the test data (unseen) was also very good as the training data (seen). Therefore, these models can predict the values of the dependent variables using independent variables in the best way. In next, GP as an optimal modeling method was applied to find the optimal catalyst and study of the influences of synthesis parameters on SAPO-34 catalyst performance.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of synthesis parameters on the performance of nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalysts
3.3.1. Effect of amount of DEA and CNT templates
sections.text:
Fig. 10 demonstrates the effect of the two DEA and CNT templates in the initial gel on the light olefins selectivity and conversion of methanol in the MTO process, 9 h after the onset of the reaction. It can be observed that by increasing the amount of the DEA template, the light olefins selectivity decreased due to a decrease in catalyst lifetime. According to the previous study of the author’s research team, with the increase in DEA level, the surface area of the micropores, which is indicative of the crystallinity of the crystals formed, and the BET level
DEA/Al2O3 CNT/Al2O3 Crystallization Time (h) Ultrasonic irradiation Intensity (W/cm2) Ultrasonic irradiation Time (min) Yield of light olefins after 9 h

increased, however, the outer surface of the samples reduced [27]. This finding indicated that decrease in the DEA amount (to the extent that it does not cause the transfer of the CHA phase (SAPO-34) to AFI (SAPO5) and the destruction of the SAPO-34 structure), albeit reducing the crystallinity of the sample, reduces the size of the crystals produced, improving the outer surface of the samples and hence their lifetime and performance in long time [27]. This figure also shows that by increasing the amount of CNT to the CNT/Al2O3 ratio value of 1, the light olefins selectivity and conversion of methanol increases. In other words, the increase in CNT, on the one hand, causes introduction of the mesopores and even macropores into the SAPO-34 structure and creation of a nano-hierarchical structure, and hence, the reaction products can be quickly transferred to the outside environment after being produced [27]. On the other hand, this leads to the creation of smaller and unagglomerated particles, and the external surface of the samples increases [27]. In fact, the catalyst with a nano-hierarchical structure allows the entry of more meso-pores be subjected to molecular diffusion, hence increasing the specific surface area. All of these factors lead to the increased catalyst lifetime and as a result, better performance in
the MTO process after 9 h [27]. But, the interesting point predicted by the genetic model is that when the CNT/Al2O3 ratio reaches a value greater than 1, a further increase in the CNT value in the initial gel not only does not improve the nano-hierarchical structure and, hence, its performance in the MTO process, but it also weakens its performance. This can be justified by the fact that the excessive entry of CNTs into the SAPO-34 structure can significantly weaken the microporous structure of the SAPO-34, thus diminishing the performance and light olefins selectivity in the MTO process [27].

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Effect of crystallization time
sections.text:
The effect of the amount of DEA and crystallization time on the conversion of methanol, and light olefins selectivity after 9 h from the onset of the process has been illustrated in Fig. 11. As shown in this figure, the methanol conversion, and light olefins selectivity increase when crystallization time increases up to 5 h, but decline with further increase in the crystallization time. According to the previous study of the author’s research team, by increasing the crystallization time up to 5 h, catalysts with higher purity and crystallinity, and hence with a better process performance, are produced. However, with a further increase of the crystallization time, catalysts consisting of agglomerated crystals with larger size and smaller outer surface are formed which reduce their performance in the MTO process [27]. Besides, it is observed that in higher crystallization time (more than 6 h), the catalyst performance decreases with increasing DEA, but in lower amounts of the crystallization time (< 6 h), with increasing DEA template up to the ratio value of DEA/Al2O3= 3, in the MTO process, the performance of the synthesized catalysts is improved. In fact, in lower crystallization times, higher amounts of the DEA template are required to produce
high purity and crystallinity of SAPO-34 catalysts and. Nevertheless, in the MTO process, the performance of the synthesized catalysts decreases with further increase in this ratio, which can be attributed to the growth of the resulting crystals with increasing the amount of DEA. As a result, the outer surface of the catalysts, which plays a significant role in the performance of the SAPO-34 catalyst, decreases [27].

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Effect of time and power intensity of ultrasonic irradiation waves
sections.text:
Fig. 12 demonstrates the effect of the variables associated with the irradiation of the ultrasound waves on the target variables (conversion of methanol and light olefins selectivity) in the MTO process. It can be seen that in the short time of irradiation of the ultrasound waves, with the increase in the power intensity of the ultrasound waves, the conversion of methanol, and also the light olefins selectivity increases. In other words, increasing the intensity of ultrasound waves decreases the size of produced nano-catalyst particles. In addition, by increasing the power intensity of the ultrasound waves, the time required to synthesize a high-crystallinity catalyst decreases, resulting in a catalyst with high crystallinity [13]. In the MTO process, these factors lead to the improvement of the performance of the SAPO-34 catalyst. However, in longer radiation times, the methanol conversion, and light olefins selectivity have maximum value versus power intensity; this finding is consistent with the results reported in previous studies [13,14]. It can be claimed the high-energy waves result in the structure degradation or alteration, thus diminishing the crystallinity of the produced particles.
Furthermore, in constant power intensities, when the intensity of ultrasonic waves is low, the conversion of methanol, and light olefins selectivity increase with increasing irradiation time. In fact, insufficient and non-uniform mixing of the solution is performed during low irradiation times by the ultrasonic waves, and in this short time, fewer cavitation bubbles, and hence the primary crystalline nuclei are likely to form [13,14]. Besides, in this short time, there is not a possibility for the enough growth of SAPO-34 crystals [13,14]. In contrast, at higher times, a large number of initial crystalline nuclei form and grow continuously until the level of super-saturation of the solution is reduced [14]. Afterwards, further growth of crystals is not possible. This issue is indicative of an increase in crystallinity and a decrease in the average particle size with increasing radiation time [14]. However, in the high intensity of ultrasonic waves, particles with the best performance are obtained in the MTO process at optimum times of radiation of the waves. Indeed, with the increase in the time of emission of ultrasonic waves up to the optimal amount, the sample crystallinity is increased, and a catalyst with a smaller particle size is obtained [14,27]. In other words, the further increase in the radiation time from the optimal radiation time in the high-intensity ultrasound waves causes the structure degradation, and thus reduced the crystallinity of the particles produced at long radiation times [14]. Therefore, its performance drops in the MTO process.

sections.heading: 3.4. Finding the optimal nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst
sections.text:
The GA optimization algorithm was adopted to find the optimal catalyst with the best performance in the MTO process. In most cases, the fitness function and the objective function are the same as the objective is to either maximize or minimize the given evaluation function. In this method, the maximum yield of light olefins after 9 h from the process was used as the objective function defined as below:
= ×Light olefins Yield Methanol conversion Light olefins selectivity (20)
GP models calculate the light olefins yield. Table 7 displays the optimal catalyst found by the GA with the highest light olefins yield after 9 h of the process.
In the following, the optimal catalyst introduced was synthesized and its performance after 9 h from the onset of the MTO process were compared with the results of genetic prediction models, as presented in Table 8. It can be observed that genetic models could well predict the empirical results. Fig. 13a, and b represent the results of the XRD and FESEM analyses for the optimal synthesized SAPO-34 catalyst. According to the XRD peaks (Fig. 13a) and comparing them with those reported for SAPO-34 [27], the optimum SAPO-34 catalyst was pure without amorphous phase. As can be seen in Fig. 13b, adding CNTs as mesopore template and using ultrasound irradiation during the SAPO34 synthesis remarkably changed the particle morphology, so that, in optimum SAPO-34, spherical nanoparticles are seen instead of the common, cubic shape for SAPO-34 particles [27]. Moreover, the distribution of products in the MTO process using optimized catalyst is depicted in Fig. 13c. As seen in Fig. 13c, the optimum SAPO-34 showed a good methanol conversion and selectivity of light olefins (ethylene and propylene) at long times. Also, because of its hierarchical structure, it showed great resistance to coke formation and deactivation, remarkably increasing the catalyst lifetime.
In previous work of askari and halladj [14], SAPO-34 nano-catalysts were synthesized using ultrasound-assisted hydrothermal. In their study, the best catalyst sample synthesized in similar process conditions of the present study had a yield of 10% relative to the light olefins after a period of 9 h from the start of the process. Dimethyl ether (DME) accounted for most of the products produced in this period, which was undesirable [14]. However, as it was observed, the optimal catalyst in the current study had a yield of 72% relative to light olefins after 9 h; this significant increase in performance can be attributed to the creation of a nano-hierarchical structure in the optimal catalyst.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In the present study, the effect of main parameters on sonochemical synthesis of hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst – i.e., crystallization time, ultrasonic irradiation time and power intensity and amount of organic templates (CNT and DEA) – on its performance in the MTO process was investigated and modeled using classical (MLR) and intelligent methods (ANN and GP). The results revealed that the models achieved using the GP method had the highest accuracy for training and test data. Therefore, these models were used to predict the effect of catalyst synthesis parameters. The predictions showed that increasing the amount of CNT template creates a nano-hierarchical structure in the catalyst, also, the time and intensity of irradiation of the ultrasound waves, increase the lifetime of the catalyst and improve its performance at long times (9 h after the beginning of the reaction). Nevertheless, with the excessive increase in the values of the above variables, the catalyst performance drops due to the degradation of its structure. Moreover, the performance of the catalyst improves by decreasing the DEA level (to the extent that it does not cause the phase transfer from SAPO-34 to SAPO-5). Therefore, the optimal values of the synthesis variables and hence the optimal catalyst with the highest light olefins yield should be found, which the GA method was used for this purpose. Genetic models were exploited as the evaluation function in GA. The results predicted for the optimal catalyst were well consistent with the experimental results and showed high efficiency for light olefins after 9 h after the start of the process.

metadata.abstractText: The present study has focused on performance analysis of ultrasound-assisted synthesized nano-hierarchical silico-alumino-phosphate-34 (SAPO-34) catalyst during methanol-to-light-olefins (MTO) process. A classical method, i.e., multiple linear regression (MLR) and two intelligent methods, i.e., genetic programming (GP) and artificial neural networks (ANN) were used for modeling of the performance of nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst. We studied the influence of basic parameters for the sonochemical synthesis of nano-hierarchical SAPO34 catalyst such as crystallization time, ultrasonic irradiation time, ultrasonic intensity, amount of organic template (diethylamine (DEA) and carbon nanotube (CNT)) on its performance (methanol conversion and light olefins selectivity) in MTO process. The results revealed that the models achieved using the GP method had the highest accuracy for training and test data. Therefore, GP models were used in the following to predict the effect of main parameters for the sonochemical synthesis of nano-hierarchical SAPO-34 catalyst. Finally, an optimal catalyst with the highest yield into light olefins was predicted using the genetic optimization algorithm. The genetic models were employed as an evaluation function in the genetic algorithm (GA). A good agreement between the outputs of GP models for the optimal catalyst and experimental results were obtained. The optimal ultrasound-assisted synthesized nanohierarchical SAPO-34 was accompanied by light olefins selectivity of 77% and methanol conversion of 94% from the onset of the process after 9 h.
